item.title: Like a Dragon's 'Surprising' Next Title Should Lean on One Underutilized Protagonist
item.description:
Highlights

  • Like a Dragon series fans can look forward to a surprising new game announcement at the Tokyo Game Show in September.
  • Considering the past success with spin-offs, fans speculate on a potential game featuring an underutilized protagonist, Shun Akiyama.
  • Akiyama's adventures in Singapore post-Yakuza 6 could set the stage for a new international Like a Dragon game, offering fresh character development and exploration.

After solid back-to-back releases for the Like a Dragon series and an upcoming live-action TV adaptation, fans of Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio's seminal franchise are being treated quite well. On top of the Amazon show set for release in October, RGG Studio has announced their plans to unveil the next Like a Dragon game at this year's Tokyo Game Show in September. While not much has been shared about this upcoming title, the developer has stated that fans will be "surprised" by it, leading many to believe this new entry will be something never before seen in the series.

It's not uncommon for the Like a Dragon franchise to get experimental with its games. From spin-offs that shed modern yakuza storylines in favor of feudal Japanese settings and even a zombie apocalypse, to a complete genre shift from an action-brawler to a turn-based JRPG with Yakuza: Like a Dragon , RGG Studio has a history of keeping players on their toes. However, one way the developer could really surprise players is by shifting the focus of this new game away from the series' usual protagonists and giving an underrepresented character a turn at the helm.

The Next Like a Dragon Game Should Let Shun Akiyama Take the Wheel

Akiyama's Protagonist Status Has Been Underutilized in the Past

While Kazuma Kiryu, and more recently Ichiban Kasuga, are the faces of the Like a Dragon franchise, the series has featured other protagonists alongside these legendary characters. Yakuza 4 was the first in the series to really expand the series' protagonist roster, introducing three other playable characters — Shun Akiyama, Taiga Saejima, and Masayoshi Tanimura — alongside Kiryu. Although each character received their own dedicated arc in the game's story, Akiyama stood out as an instant fan-favorite with his charming, aloof personality as the owner of Sky Finance.

Akiyama returned as a playable protagonist in Yakuza 5 , but this time his story chapters were shared with another protagonist, Kiryu's adopted daughter Haruka Sawamura, as she worked to become Japan's biggest idol. As such, Akiyama's potential in this game felt squandered after its predecessor solidified him as a likable and popular protagonist. He appears briefly again in Yakuza 6: The Song of Life , but is quickly pushed aside as Kiryu leaves the streets of Kamurocho for the small Hiroshima town of Onomichi.

Infinite Wealth Already Sets Up the Perfect Premise for an Akiyama-Led Game

After an abrupt departure from the series in Yakuza 6 , Akiyama makes a welcome appearance in Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth as a Life Link for Kiryu. Progressing the Memoirs of a Dragon side quest and unlocking the special encounter with Akiyama reveals what he had been doing in the time between Yakuza 6 and the present day. He details how he spent time traveling the world while managing his money for fear that Ryo Aoki's Kamurocho 3K Plan could impact the gray area his Sky Finance business operates within, all while holding out hope that Kiryu is still alive.

Having returned from his trip with the news from Date that Kiryu is still alive, Akiyama notes that he spent a good chunk of his time on his own adventure in Singapore. A game that tells this story could be the perfect premise for a Like a Dragon Gaiden game starring Akiyama, as it gives the series a new location to explore in Singapore while also giving Akiyama the character development he deserves. After Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth took the series out of Japan for the first time, the floodgates have been opened for international adventures, and Akiyama's time in Singapore could be the "surprise" RGG Studio is waiting to unveil.

item.title: Skyrim: The 28 Best Two-Handed Weapons (& Where To Get Them)
item.description:
Skyrim has so much to offer its players. With countless quests to explore and an astronomical amount of mods available for the game, it's almost guaranteed that everyone will find something they enjoy while playing.

The Dragonborn is capable of dealing large swallows of damage if they know which weapons to put in their two capable hands. While Skyrim players are capable of using their Smithing skills to make some impressive weapons, there are some unique ones available in the game that should be considered for the special advantages they provide.

Updated on August 17, 2024 by Ritwik Mitra: Skyrim is one of the most popular and beloved video games that is still making waves to this day. Bethesda set the gaming landscape ablaze with an open-world sandbox that was ahead of its time, featuring sublime art direction and consistency as players explored the land of the Nords and fell in love with its many interesting locales. The beauty of Skyrim is apparent for everyone to see, but the dangers present in this world must be dealt with from time to time by the Dragonborn. The best way to do this is with good old-fashioned melee combat where players can flatten their foes with some of the best two-handed weapons in Skyrim that can destroy most enemies with ease.

28 Honed Ancient Nord Greatsword

Wielded By High-Level Draugr Enemies

  • Base Damage: 20
  • Weight: 21
  • Base Value: 63

Greatswords are some of the best two-handed weapons in Skyrim that players can get their hands on. This weapon can cleave foes in half with ease as long as players have the most powerful variants of this weapon at their disposal, and the Honed Ancient Nord Greatsword is one such weapon that deserves all its plaudits in this department.

This is a weapon that players will find on most high-level draugr enemies, making it a worthy reward for players who love exploring the many crypts and dungeons in Skyrim . It boasts high damage and becomes even more viable in combat once players find a special version of this weapon or enchant it themselves to show enemies who's boss.

27 Dawnguard Warhammer

Wielded By Dawnguard Members

  • Base Damage: 22
  • Weight: 26
  • Base Value: 110

It's only a given that any game with DLC will add a wealth of powerful weapons that players can get their hands on to destroy their foes, and the Dawnguard Warhammer is no exception here. This weapon looks great and is used by members of the Dawnguard to smash their foes. Players can purchase one such weapon from their fort, find it in chests, or loot it from an enemy if they've gone against the Dawnguard.

The weapon looks simple enough but will pummel foes with high attack values. With an enchanted variant of this weapon, players can go even further in their attempts to show enemies who's boss as they're walloped by the Dragonborn and punished for thinking that they could stand a chance against the person destined to save the world. This makes it one of the best two-handed weapons in Skyrim that's a blast to use.

26 Nord Hero Battle Axe

Can Be Crafted At The Skyforge After Completing The Companions Questline

  • Base Damage: 21
  • Weight: 20
  • Base Value: 300

The Nord Hero Battle Axe is one of the best two-handed weapons in Skyrim that player can use to show their enemies who's boss. The weapon looks great and can punish any enemy who thought it to be a prudent idea to try and take out someone as intimidating as the Dragonborn. The base variant of this weapon is quite powerful as is, so players can only imagine how much damage they can inflict once they enchant this weapon.

Unlike most of the weapons players can find or loot in Skyrim , the only way to get the Nord Hero War Axe is to forge it after completing the Companions' quest line. This can make the act of accessing this weapon way harder than most people would assume, but it won't take long for players to get their hands on a great weapon perfect for Skyrim in the early to mid-game, especially if players bring it to an enchanting table soon after.

25 Madness Greatsword

Can Be Crafted After Completing The Quest "Amber And Madness Smithing"

  • Base Damage: 26
  • Weight: 28
  • Base Value: 3,100

The Creation Club has added a wealth of premium content to Skyrim that players can opt for if regular mods aren't cutting it anymore. Most of the content comes in the form of new items that players can mess around with in the game, and the set of Madness weapons is a great incentive to opt for if players want to decimate their opponents in no time.

Wielding a greatsword in the game feels pretty satisfying, especially if players have used mods to make the combat feel more engaging. So it makes sense that using this powerful greatsword to cleave enemies is as satisfying as can be.

24 Madness Battleaxe

Can Be Crafted After Completing The Quest "Amber and Madness Smithing"

  • Base Damage: 27
  • Weight: 31
  • Base Value: 3,300

The Saints & Seducers Creation Club Content adds a bunch of stuff to Skyrim . From new enemies to unique equipment, players will find the endgame to be more engaging as they uncover everything that this content pack has to offer.

The Madness ore is one such material that is added to the game, and this is a very rare material that takes a lot of work to find. However, the end result is worth it, with players being able to craft Madness weapons like the Madness Battleaxe, which hits like a truck and ensures that any enemy who gets too comfortable with the Dragonborn will regret their decision.

23 Madness Warhammer

Can Be Crafted After Completing The Quest "Amber and Madness Smithing"

  • Base Damage: 29
  • Weight: 34
  • Base Value: 4,600

To learn how to craft items using Madness ore, players must find Evethra's Journal and read it. Along with this, players must have a Smithing skill of 80 and know the Ebony Smithing skill if they wish to make items using this powerful raw material. Meeting these requirements will let players craft some powerful Madness equipment, including the Madness Warhammer.

With this powerful weapon, players can smash enemies into the ground no matter how powerful they are. Enchanting this weapon makes it even more viable if players were prudent about that skill tree as well, but that is optional. Even in its base form, the Madness Warhammer is no joke.

22 Balgruuf's Greatsword

Quest Item Obtained During "Greatsword For A Great Man"

  • Base Damage: 17
  • Weight: 17
  • Base Value: 200

It's a shame that Balgruuf's Greatsword is a temporary item in the Dragonborn's arsenal. It's a quest item obtained during "Greatsword for a Great Man" that needs to be delivered to Jarl Balgruuf, meaning that players can only use it for a short while before turning it in.

While there are exploits that allow players to loot this weapon regardless, the effort is too much considering that the Dragonborn will find better weapons later. That being said, it's the limited time with this weapon that makes it fun to use, even if it may not be for too long.

21 Stormfang

Looted From The Body Of A Reaver Lord At Brodir Grove

  • Base Damage: 17
  • Weight: 17
  • Base Value: 1175

Players who explore Brodin Grove and defeat the Reaver Lord will get a chance to wield this weapon. The Stormfang is pretty powerful and can slice through enemies in a flash.

After all, this weapon does Shock damage with every hit, taking away an enemy's Magicka in the process, too. Players who love elemental weapons will also get a kick out of using Stormfang in Skyrim .

20 Trollsbane

Found Inside Cradle Stone Crag, A Troll Den

  • Base Damage: 20
  • Weight: 25
  • Base Value: 60

Players need to explore Cradle Stone Crag, a troll's den, to find the Trollsbane weapon on the body of Frofnir Trollsbane. It's a powerful hammer that, fittingly enough, is especially deadly when used against trolls.

So, players should make it a point to use this weapon on trolls as much as possible to maximize its efficiency. That said, it's still effective against other enemies, making it a reliable if somewhat situational weapon.

19 Aegisbane

Found On The Body Of Alain Dufont In The Ruins Of Raldbthar

  • Base Damage: 17
  • Weight: 20
  • Base Value: 28

The ruins of Raldbthar house Alain Dufont and his group of bandits. Players need to defeat every one of them, either as a part of a quest or via the natural act of exploration and looting Dufont's body to get the Aegisbane.

This warhammer hits like a truck and deals Frost Damage to both health and Magicka on top of its high damage. Suffice it to say, any player looking for a powerful warhammer will be well-served by this weapon for quite some time.

18 The Woodsman's Friend

On The Body Of A Woodcutter Southwest Of The Conjurer's Altar And North Of Pinewatch

  • Base Damage: 17
  • Weight: 12
  • Base Value: 160

It's a shame that this axe takes too long to hit an enemy since the raw damage of The Woodsman's Friend is pretty admirable. As it stands, it's pretty impractical to use this weapon in a tough fight, even if it is pretty powerful in terms of sheer raw damage.

Players need to head north of Pinewatch to find a set of felled trees. After this, moving toward the southeastern side of Lake Illinatia will reveal the body of a dead woodcutter, with the axe lying near him on the grass.

17 Silver Greatsword

Frequently Found On The Bodies Of Silver Hand Members

  • Base Damage: 17
  • Weight: 12
  • Base Value: 160

The Silver Greatsword may look basic on the surface, but it has far more complexities than players might expect. While it can't be improved at a grindstone, its additional effects of dealing greater damage to the undead don't count as an enchantment. This means that players can add enchantments on top of it to make the sword even more deadly.

Players will only find this sword on members of the Silver Hand. Luckily, they are commonly encountered while doing quests for the Companions. If the Dragonborn needs that silver right away, they can go to one of their strongholds at Driftshade Refuge, Faldar's Tooth, Lost Knife Hideout, and Gallows Rock and take down enemies to get one.

16 Skyforge Steel Greatsword

Sold By Eorlund Gray-Mane in Whiterun

  • Base Damage: 20
  • Weight: 17
  • Base Value: 140

Most people would scoff at the idea of a lowly steel sword being compared to the best two-handed weapons in Skyrim , but it's the utility of the Skyforge Steel Sword that makes it so useful in the early game. If players have the gold to spare, they should purchase this weapon to make combat easier and more satisfying.

For a steel weapon, this weapon boasts an impressive attack power that can trouble enemies quite a bit. Sure, players will discard this weapon after reaching the mid to late-game, but this two-handed blade will serve them nicely until then.

15 The Rueful Axe

Obtained During The Quest "A Daedra's Best Friend"

  • Base Damage: 22
  • Weight: 10
  • Base Value: 500

This powerful — if somewhat slow — axe whittles down the stamina of any opponent unfortunate enough to be struck by this instrument of pain. The Rueful Axe is quite a blast to use in battle, although its novelty might wear off after a point.

Players need to initiate the quest "A Daedra's Best Friend" and kill the unfortunate Barbas with this axe (no other weapon will do the job) to get this axe as a reward.

14 Drainblood Battleaxe

A Ghost Weapon Obtained On Special Draugr Variants In Labyrinthian During "The Staff of Magnus"

  • Base Damage: 21
  • Weight: 5
  • Base Value: 266

This unique Nordic battleaxe is one of four ghost weapons available in the game. While it can't be upgraded at a grindstone, the fact that its health absorption doesn't require charges to use is incredibly convenient.

The only time these are available to grab is during the quest The Staff of Magnus in the College of Winterhold questline. Players will need to make sure to grab one while they're in Labyrinthian.

13 Dragonbone Battleaxe

A Relatively Common Battleaxe At Higher Levels

  • Base Damage: 26
  • Weight: 30
  • Base Value: 3000

The Dragonbone weapons introduced in the Dawnguard expansion are easily some of the best two-handed weapons in Skyrim . Their stats are immense, with the Dragonbone Battleaxe serving as a great example of what these weapons are capable of in the right hands.

These weapons are very rare drops in the world of Skyrim. Thus, most players would find it more reliable to fight the Keepers in the Soul Cairn to obtain this imposing weapon.

12 Headsman's Axe

A Unique Greataxe Wielded By Ahtar

  • Base Damage: 17
  • Weight: 11
  • Base Value: 15

The Headsman's Axe looks incredibly unique but doesn't deal as much base damage as other two-handed weapons. Still, it makes this list for its massive range, as the Headsman's Axe is the longest weapon in the entire game. Giving it proper enchantments can allow players to keep other melee-based enemies far away while taking them down.

The only way to get this axe is by taking it from Ahtar after the execution in Solitude. This can be done peacefully by getting him as a follower and taking it from his inventory or violently by just killing Ahtar outright. Either way, it's the perfect weapon to use with the Decapitation perk and is a unique choice that even long-time players of the game may have never tried.

11 Dragonbone Greatsword

A Relatively Common Greatsword At Higher Levels

  • Base Damage: 25
  • Weight: 27
  • Base Value: 2725

This is another Dragonbone weapon that pulls no punches when it comes to its sheer power and effectiveness. The Dragonbone Greatsword can cleave through enemies with immense power, destroying weak foes with a single hit.

As is the case with the Dragonbone Battleaxe, the Greatsword can also be obtained randomly by defeating and searching the remains of Keepers in the Soul Cairn. Smithing can also be used to craft a Dragonbone Greatsword. However, the requirement for a Smithing level of 100 coupled with the Dragon Armor perk can put some fans off this rather tedious method of crafting the weapon.

10 Dragonbone Warhammer

A Relatively Common Warhammer At Higher Levels

  • Base Damage: 28
  • Weight: 33
  • Base Value: 4275

Rounding off the trio of Dragonbone weapons on this list is the Dragonbone Warhammer, a massive two-handed weapon that packs a huge punch with every hit and can obliterate enemies with its smash damage.

At this point, it should be obvious how players can get this weapon. As is the case with the other Dragonbone weapons on this list, the Dragonbone Warhammer can be found on the remains of defeated Keepers in the Soul Cairn.

9 Daedric Battleaxe

A Powerful Battleaxe That Becomes Common At Higher Levels

  • Base Damage: 25
  • Weight: 27
  • Base Value: 2750

Most Daedric weapons in Skyrim can decimate foes with ease, and the Daedric Battleaxe is no exception to this rule. This axe is easily one of Skyrim 's best two-handed weapons and is extremely easy to obtain once players hit level 30 and above. Most merchants and chests in the game world will start spawning this weapon around this level.

Of course, players can go a step beyond and try to get an enchanted Daedric Battleaxe as well. However, netting this loot involves fighting a powerful dragon, and even then, this drop isn't guaranteed.

item.title: Helldivers 2’s New Booster Makes the Line Between High-Level and Casual Play Clear as Day
item.description:
Highlights

  • Helldivers 2's newest Premium Warbond, "Freedom's Flame," introduces the risky but rewarding Firebomb Hellpods booster.
  • Helldivers 2's community has mixed feelings about Firebomb Hellpods as they do about most new content updates since the booster can lead to hilarious friendly fire moments, cinematic enemy kills in a pinch, or accidental team and objective kills.

Helldivers 2 isn’t having the greatest time in the sun at the moment despite player counts remaining healthy and new content being airdropped in via the new Escalation of Freedom update and “Freedom’s Flame” Premium Warbond. Warbonds are nothing new to Helldivers 2 , but each new bit of content the third-person live-service shooter introduces does seem to push the envelope a bit and iterate on what it’s done before. “Viper Commandos” was a huge proponent of this as it debuted cosmetic palettes for Hellpods, the Pelican, and Exosuits, and “Freedom’s Flame” is thankfully more of the same.

Each Premium Warbond so far in Helldivers 2 has been particularly themed, and even though there has been some vocal backlash about nerfs and such it has been thrilling to blanket environments with sweeping sprays of flame and incendiary shotgun shells, especially in defense campaign missions where players can hold waves of Terminids back with billowing walls of fire. However, the most spectacular and perilous new addition to players’ fiery arsenals is the Firebomb Hellpods booster, which is well worth making one’s way through “Freedom’s Flame” to unlock but equally dreadful.

Helldivers 2’s Firebomb Hellpods Call Down Destruction in a Pinch

Firebomb Hellpods create an explosion on the impact of literally any Hellpod called in thanks to them being lined with “volatile incendiaries.” So far, Helldivers 2 players have known that when they drop in and surface from a Hellpod embedded in the planet they’ll need to have some semblance of a plan in place shortly thereafter. How that formulates is typically orchestrated before players even land on a planet, though, as they must select a loadout of stratagems and boosters along with their chosen primary weapon, secondary weapon, and throwable.

The meta surrounding boosters hasn’t deviated largely from what it’s always been. In any squad of four players, it is uncommon not to see at least three out of four of the following: Hellpod Space Optimization , Vitality Enhancement, Stamina Enhancement, and Flexible Reinforcement Budget.

Now, the Firebomb Hellpods booster may slowly start to be integrated into players’ loadouts for whoever has decided to fork over the cash for the Premium Warbond. One of its most obvious advantages is that it’s employed offensively and can come in clutch when support stratagems or even a resupply arrives after a tense cooldown amid a ton of enemies, let alone when reinforced players dive back into Helldivers 2 . On the other hand, the fiery explosion that ensues is indiscriminate in who or what it incinerates before the Hellpod’s actual content becomes available.

Helldivers 2’s Firebomb Hellpods are as Risky as They are Rewarding

Interestingly, most of the community has already rallied against Firebomb Hellpods and decried them as a waste of a booster. Of course, anyone who is unaware that Hellpods will detonate can easily be caught in its explosion, which is definitely the case if a random player answers a distress call and suddenly everyone’s Hellpods cause splashes of glorious fire. One of the most egregious and accidental ways Firebomb Hellpods can be disastrous is when players have little control of where their pod will land, especially on “Evacuate High-Value Assets” if they land directly on a generator and fail the mission.

Players can know to be mindful of the blue beams of light indicating a support Hellpod’s pinpointed arrival, but again without considering they may be explosive players usually hover around so they can collect whatever they called a Hellpod in for anyway. In this case, Firebomb Hellpods may be seen as teamkill in Helldivers 2 more than they actually aid teammates as it can be difficult to coordinate where they’re landing, and if players are calling them in to detonate a certain area it might so happen that other players are in the vicinity, too.

It’s also true that there are far more effective and valuable boosters if players are on the highest Helldivers 2 difficulties, but experimentation with not only new additions to the game but also anything that contributes to casual fun is a big reason why Helldivers 2 is popular in the first place. So much of what makes for hysterical moments in Helldivers 2 stems from hilarious friendly fire, though it’s understandable why so many players also despise it and kick others if they’re indulging in it. In the meantime, it’ll be interesting to see how players respond to anyone who does bring Firebomb Hellpods and their advantages can hopefully outweigh their disadvantages.

item.title: 6 2000s World War 2 Games That Are Still Great
item.description:
Highlights

  • The WW2 gaming genre has a rich history dating back to Wolfenstein 3D, offering players a variety of realistic and action-filled experiences.
  • Gamers can engage in iconic battles like D-Day in Medal of Honor: Frontline, tackle strategy and destruction in Company of Heroes, or liberate Paris in The Saboteur.
  • Dive into the tactical side of WW2 with games like Commandos 2 and Brothers in Arms: Road to Hill 30, offering challenging missions and historical accuracy.

Ever since being in the mainstream, gaming and WW2 themes have been closely tied together. The most notable early example would be Wolfenstein 3D , which was released in 1992. From that point onward, and likely also thanks to the film Saving Private Ryan , there has been an abundance of WW2 games that have been released over the years.

From Medal of Honor , to Call of Duty , to the aforementioned Wolfenstein , gamers are never short of opportunities to scratch their WW2 itch. Due to the hundreds (if not thousands) of games in this setting (all with varying levels of quality and entertainment value), it can be hard to know which are worth playing, especially with a never-slowing influx of WW2-themed game releases. For those looking for a fun WW2 experience, the 2000s is a great era to check out.

6 Medal Of Honor: Frontline

A Memorable Classic That Offers A Realistic Vision Of WW2

One of the older titles on this list, Medal of Honor: Frontline was released during the sixth console generation, yet it still holds up well to this day. Frontline attempts to focus on realism first, with the playable missions being based closely on real world battles and campaigns that took place during the Second World War. It also features an authentic list of well-known WW2 weapons for a player to enjoy.

The missions themselves are fun and varied, with large-scale battles, like the Omaha beach assault on D-Day, to slower, stealth-based infiltration missions. After each mission is completed, players are given a performance evaluation with stats and a grading, which really adds to the replayability. To top it off, the fantastic soundtrack is the icing on the cake.

5 Company Of Heroes

Strategy Meets Epic WW2 Destruction

With the third game in the now iconic Company of Heroes series not being too far in the rearview mirror, now is the perfect time to jump back into the first entry. This excellent RTS game improves on the normal tropes seen within the genre, requiring control points to be captured to gain resources instead of having to gather those resources individually. This feature gives players more time to enjoy the action, which is where Company of Heroes really shines.

Featuring fully destructible environments and smart squad AI, Company of Heroes players will feel like they are watching a war movie at times. The campaign includes 15 well-designed missions with a good range of objectives, and the multiplayer and skirmish modes add to the mix by allowing players to play as both the Allied and Axis factions.

4 The Saboteur

An Open-World Game Set In Nazi-Occupied Paris

The Saboteur is the final game released by the legendary developer 'Pandemic Studios,' and they made sure they went out with a bang. This open-world action game places the player in a Nazi-occupied Paris with the goal of liberating the city via acts of sabotage. Occupied zones find themselves in black and white and only gain color when liberated, which is a nice reminder to show the player that they're making a difference in the world.

Gameplay-wise, The Saboteur has tight gunplay, and traversing the world is incredibly fun thanks to the great mix of vehicles and the ability to climb any surface. The open-world also has a good number of side missions that can be completed before or after finishing the main game.

3 Call Of Duty: World At War

A Gritty And Action-Packed Look At World War 2

The ever popular Call of Duty series has featured a WW2 setting in many of its titles, including some more recent ones, which has meant that the best of these, seen in World at War , has fallen a bit to the wayside. This gritty, action-packed entry attempts (and succeeds) to show the horrors of war, and it doesn't pull any punches when doing so.

The campaign features a great variety of missions in different world locations, from the Pacific and all through Europe, and never outstays its welcome. The multiplayer mode is fun as would be expected from a Call of Duty title, featuring well-designed maps and fun weapons to use and upgrade.

2 Commandos 2: Men Of Courage

A Strategy Game In Which Players Sneak Behind Enemy Lines

Officially the oldest title on this list, Commandos 2: Men of Courage shows its age with the graphics and gameplay department, but there's more than enough charm to make it still be worth playing.

This is an RTS game with a steep learning curve and a real emphasis on strategy. All squadmates the player controls have their own skills and abilities, from a demolitions expert to a green beret, and these will have to be utilized correctly to have a chance of success through 12 well-designed and challenging missions.

1 Brothers In Arms: Road To Hill 30

A Tactical WW2 Experience

The first game in the Brothers in Arms series, Brothers in Arms: Road to Hill 30 , puts the player in the shoes of Sgt. Matt Baker as he leads his squad of 101st Airbourne Paratroopers through France just prior to the D-Day invasion. Upon first glance, this may look like the usual run-of-the-mill WW2 FPS, but the real focus is on tactics, as enemy squads are just as deadly as the paratroopers, so suppressing and flanking foes is key.

Road to Hill 30 is also one of the more accurate-to-history WW2 games, as the overall story is closely tied to real events and battles, and the environments were designed to look as they would have in 1944.

item.title: Diablo 4: How To Get Blood Moon Breeches Unique
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How To Get Blood Moon Breeches In Diablo 4
  • Blood Moon Breeches Effect & Affixes In Diablo 4

One of the most popular builds in Diablo 4 is the Minion Necromancer. With various buffs and variants, Minion Necromancers can solo different endgame activities thanks to their army of undead getting the job done. Thankfully, the sheer power of the Necromancer can be boosted by the different Necro Unique items that will make them near unstoppable.

That is where the Blood Moon Breeches enter the equation. These Unique pants will make your Minions a force to be reckoned with by passively using skills that will get you out of trouble more often than not. Thankfully, Unique farming is not as difficult and repetitive as before, so this guide will focus on the different ways you can get the Blood Moon Breeches in Diablo 4 .

How To Get Blood Moon Breeches In Diablo 4

To get the Blood Moon Breeches Unique pants, you can start by either opening chests or defeating enemies in World Tier 3 and World Tier 4 in Diablo 4 . While Unique drop chances have improved throughout the game's lifespan, your best shot at getting the Blood Moon Breeches this way is to engage in endgame activities such as Nightmare Dungeons, Gathering Legions, Helltides, and joining players in defeating World Bosses across Sanctuary.

The Blood Moon Breeches were introduced during Diablo 4 Season 2, a season that also saw the implementation of the Uber Boss activities . Uniques are part of a specific Uber Boss loot pool, allowing for greater drop chances at a higher risk due to the difficulty of the fights. Blood Moon Breaches are among the special Unique items that will require you to fight either Duriel, King of Maggots , or the Echo of Andariel , both exclusive to World Tier 4 and whose summoning materials are dropped by other Uber Bosses, as you can see in the table below:

Boss

Location

Materials

Duriel

Gaping Crevasse, Kehjistan

  • 2x Mucus-Slick Egg : Defeat Echo of Varshan.
  • 2x Shard of Agony : Defeat Grigoire, the Galvanic Saint.

Tormented Duriel

Gaping Crevasse, Kehjistan

  • 6x Mucus-Slick Egg
  • 6x Shard of Agony
  • 1x Stygian Stone : Open reward chests after completing The Pit runs.

Andariel

Hanged Man's Hall, Kehjistan

  • 2x Sandscorched Shackles : Defeat Lord Zir, the Dark Master.
  • 2x Pincushioned Doll : Defeat The Beast in the Ice.

Tormented Andariel

Hanged Man's Hall, Kehjistan

  • 6x Sandscorched Shackles
  • 6x Pincushioned Doll
  • 1x Stygian Stone

As you can see, out of the two versions for each Uber Boss, the Tormented versions are by far the most difficult to prepare in Diablo 4 . This is because Stygian Stones will require The Pit run completions, with The Pit being a particularly difficult activity on its own. However, you will also have a better chance at getting Unique items, so getting the Blood Moon Breeches by defeating Tormented Duriel or Tormented Andariel will be the best way to farm them — as long as you are prepared to do so.

Blood Moon Breeches Effect & Affixes In Diablo 4

If your Necromancer equips the Blood Moon Breaches Unique, then your Minions will have a 3-7% chance of randomly inflicting Decrepify or Iron Maiden . Additionally, any enemies afflicted by your curses will receive a 100-150% damage increase . You will also receive the following effects thanks to the Blood Moon Breeches's Affixes:

  • +[88.0-115.0]% Overpower Damage
  • +[26.0-35.0]% Curse Duration
  • +[638-873] Maximum Life
  • +[2-4] to Curse Skills
